title: How do you type an X Bar
content:
My wife is currently in a stats class in her masters program and asked me how she would go about typing an X Bar. I've attached an image of the character. I've done some digging around online and found the character mentioned on [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/ta.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%A3%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%A4%E0%AE%95%E0%AF%8D_%E0%AE%95%E0%AF%81%E0%AE%B1%E0%AE%BF%E0%AE%AF%E0%AF%80%E0%AE%9F%E0%AF%81%E0%AE%95%E0%AE%B3%E0%AF%8D) (third character from the bottom).

I see that Lucida Sans Unicode has it as a character, and I can copy and paste the X bar from that page into Word when using that font. I've checked the Character Map in Windows and couldn't find it, so I'm curious though how I would go about typing this on a PC. Is there a key combination using the Alt key + a series of numbers?

Thanks for any help.  
David

comments.content: I don't think that the x-bar (or any other letter-bar) is included in a standard font set. Normally, the typesetting program will add the bar itself by writing the letter and then drawing the line over the top. If you want a symbol like this in Word, you should be able to use the Microsoft Equation plugin (something like Insert \> Object \> Microsoft Equation x.x). You can use the dialog that appears to create the x-bar (and a whole equation that includes it). If you're looking to use mathematics symbols seriously, consider the LaTeX typesetting system.

x̄  
For the web at least, here is how you can do it.  
 [http://www.personal.psu.edu/ejp10/psu/gotunicode/statsym.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/www.personal.psu.edu/ejp10/psu/gotunicode/statsym.html "http://www.personal.psu.edu/ejp10/psu/gotunicode/statsym.html")

This should apply to regular programs as well, I'm not entirely clear on unicode support in non-web contexts, but it appears to work in most. For example copy and paste the x here. It should work in most apps.

BTW. Character map doesn't show it because this is actually one regular character and then a special modifier TO the character. The x here may not be correct, but the modifier should be.

For typesetting formulas in academia the usual tool is [TeX](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TeX). TeX editors are available as free software for most operating systems. The TeX system will create any symbol used in mathematics and statistics.
Great! Thanks everyone for your help.

As an alternative to Word's equation editor, [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/sbarnhill.mvps.org/WordFAQs/Overbar.htm) page explains how to construct an overstrike character and assign a shortcut key.

But for doing statistics or other math, wouldn't a math pi font be a better solution in the long run? The American Mathematical Society has free Postscript distributions of Computer Modern and AMSFonts at [http://www.ams.org/tex/type1-fonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/www.ams.org/tex/type1-fonts.html). TrueType versions are on the Mozilla website at [http://www.mozilla.org/projects/mathml/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/www.mozilla.org/projects/mathml/fonts/).  
Wolfram's downloadable Mathematica 6.0 fonts are at [http://support.wolfram.com/mathematica/systems/windows/general/latestfonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/support.wolfram.com/mathematica/systems/windows/general/latestfonts.html), and MathType fonts are at [http://www.dessci.com/en/dl/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218042732/http:/www.dessci.com/en/dl/fonts/).

(These are all properly licensed or donated fonts, so I don't believe the links violate any Typophile rules.)

Gus

But is there an x bar character in those AMS fonts? I haven't set maths for a long time, but I recall that the x bar was created by an overline on the x, not a specific character.

\> But is there an x bar character in those AMS fonts?

You're probably right. I, too, don't work with scientific material any more and don't have any math fonts installed, but I did have a vague memory of using a font that had an x-bar, and those fonts are the usual suspects. Of course, given that this is Monday, I might be thinking of h-bar.
